Trump fires Federal Labor Relations Authority member President Donald Trump fired Susan Tsui Grundmann, who until Tuesday served as chair of the Federal Labor Relations Authority, a White House official confirmed. Grundmann’s firing from the agency tasked with overseeing public-sector unions appears to violate federal law that protects the agency’s board members from removal by the president without cause. In recent days, Trump has also taken the extraordinary step of firing members of the National Labor Relations Board and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The unprecedented wave of firings appears to contravene a 1935 Supreme Court ruling that shields the leaders of independent agencies from removal by the president “except in cases of neglect of duty, malfeasance or inefficiency.” Grundmann’s term was set to expire in July. A White House official said about the firing that Trump is committed to building a team that advances his “America First” agenda. Everett Kelley, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, the largest federal workers’ union, said in a statement that Grundmann’s termination was “one more piece of evidence demonstrating this administration is engaged in a continued, unlawful attack on federal workers.”
